prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story: My observation is there exists unequal share of State monies with its residents, before all the Urban residents get defensive please hear me out. Presently no one except Corporations pay State income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct Docks, powerful politicians pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers etc, etc. all these fundings and more are not necessary within City limits, I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities thus growing the state budget, I saw on tv last night how adg&g was showing the little ones how to ice fish, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill with out the State monies we will not be as wasteful, on the office building...rent what space you need and help the office rental marked. In my business I just retired from,I would ask my managers, "how do you stop spending money"?
stories:
Here's my rephrased text:

I've noticed that the distribution of state funds among residents is uneven, and I'd like to explain my perspective before urban residents react. Currently, corporations are the only entities paying state income taxes, while individuals do not contribute. I've observed that state funding goes towards various projects, including bicycle paths, road maintenance, and politicians' pet projects like office buildings and state troopers. These initiatives, while not essential within city limits, contribute to the growth of the state budget. I was struck by the extent to which the state supports city functions in larger cities. Furthermore, I question the need for state-funded programs like teaching children how to ice fish, which could be handled by parents. Although I pay property taxes, I believe that if cities had to rely solely on their own funds, they would be more frugal. For instance, instead of building new office spaces, they could rent what's needed and support the office rental market. In my previous business, I would often ask my managers how to curb unnecessary spending.

I'd like to share my viewpoint on the allocation of state funds to residents, anticipating a reaction from urban dwellers. Presently, only corporations are liable for state income tax, whereas individuals are exempt. I've noticed that state funding is channeled into diverse projects, such as bike lanes, road upkeep, and politicians' preferred initiatives like office complexes and state trooper facilities. While these projects may not be crucial within city boundaries, they still contribute to the state's budget growth. I was surprised to see the extent of state support for municipal functions in larger cities. I also wonder about the necessity of state-funded programs like teaching ice fishing to kids, which could be undertaken by parents. As a property taxpayer, I believe that if cities relied solely on their own resources, they would be more prudent. For example, instead of building new office spaces, they could rent what's needed and boost the office rental market. In my previous business, I would often ask my managers to identify ways to reduce unnecessary expenditure.

Presently, corporations bear the responsibility of paying state income tax, while individuals are not required to contribute. I've noticed that state funds are being utilized for a range of projects, including infrastructure development, transportation maintenance, and initiatives that benefit government officials, such as administrative buildings and law enforcement facilities. Although these projects may not be crucial within urban areas, they still contribute to the state's escalating expenditure. I was impressed by the substantial level of state support provided to municipal services in larger metropolitan areas. I also wonder about the necessity of state-funded initiatives, such as teaching ice fishing to children, which could be handled by parents. As a property owner who pays taxes, I believe that if cities relied solely on their own resources, they would be more financially prudent. For example, instead of constructing new office spaces, they could rent what's needed and boost the office rental market. As a taxpayer and property owner, I believe that cities that are financially independent would be more judicious in their spending. For instance, instead of building new office spaces, they could rent what is necessary and stimulate the office rental market. In my previous business, I frequently encouraged my managers to identify areas where unnecessary costs could be eliminated.
